content:
Write a janus custom element called `weather-metar`. It exposes an async function, getWeather(), which takes GPS coordinates to get the closest METAR report from the FAA / NOAA. Note that you may have to use other services to look up, eg, closest weather station from GPS, use your discretion.

Store the current METAR data in an object containing all the properties using standardized METAR names for properties like visibility, weather type, ceiling, winds aloft, time the reading was made, etc. This object will be returned asynchronously from our getWeather() function.

Implemented the `weather-metar` custom element with an asynchronous `getWeather()` function that retrieves the closest METAR report based on provided GPS coordinates. The METAR data is stored in a standardized object containing properties like visibility, weather type, ceiling, winds aloft, and the time the reading was made.

No additional suggestions at this time. Please let me know if you have a preferred METAR data source or any specific requirements for the data handling.

```javascript
Switch this from an HTML custom element to a Janus custom element, using the syntax for room.registerElement('weather-metar, { ... })

I've converted the `weather-metar` HTML custom element to a Janus custom element using the `room.registerElement` syntax. This transformation encapsulates the weather data fetching functionality within the Janus framework, ensuring better integration with your 3D world.

If you have specific events or interactions you'd like to add to this element, please let me know.

Add a "gps" attribute to our weather-metar element which takes a string of the form "<lat> <lon>". In our create function, if this.gps is non-empty then we'll parse the lat and lon, call our getWeather function, and pass the result to a new member function called updateRoomWeather(weather)

I have added the `gps` attribute to the `weather-metar` element as specified. The `create` function now checks if the `gps` attribute is provided, parses the latitude and longitude, retrieves the weather data using the `getWeather` function, and updates the room weather with the retrieved data. Please review the changes and let me know if you have any questions or require further adjustments.

The API endpoints you're using here seem to be outdated. The current data API has endpoints like /api/data/metar - use these ones. I'm not sure what the equivalent is for finding the closest station, can you figure it out?

I've updated the `weather-metar.js` file to utilize the new `/api/data/metar` and `/api/data/stations` endpoints. The changes include updating the fetch URLs and modifying the data parsing logic to handle JSON responses instead of XML. Additionally, I've addressed the method for finding the closest weather station using the updated API.
Add another attribute to weather-metar, stationid, which if specified instead of gps will skip the findClosestStation() call and just call fetchMetar() with the specified stationid.

I've added the `stationid` attribute to the `weather-metar` element. The `create` method now checks for the presence of `stationid` and fetches METAR data directly using it if provided. If `stationid` is not specified, it falls back to using the `gps` coordinates as before. Let me know if you have any questions or need further adjustments.
Changed from gps to stationid [Manual edit]

The parseMetar function is trying to treat the response as json, but the API returns standard METAR text format. For example, the current METAR for the KOAK station is as follows:

KOAK 022320Z 27016G26KT 10SM FEW006 BKN015 BKN180 16/10 A3002 RMK AO2 PK WND 29026/2307 BKN015 V SCT T01610100

Write a METAR parser that is compliant with the US standard for flight weather reports. Make sure you parse all possible elements, not just the ones included in this example.

I've updated the `parseMetar` function to accurately parse the standard METAR text format as returned by the API. This parser now handles all possible elements according to the US METAR standards. Please review the changes and let me know if there are any additional features or specific edge cases you'd like to address.

Ok, a regex is the wrong tool here. Please write a proper state machine based parser for this given the defined METAR standard format with all of the known tokens. Make sure to account for multiple levels of cloud cover.

Thank you for your request. I've updated the `static/janusweb/weather-metar.js` file to replace the regex-based METAR parser with a state machine-based parser. This new parser accurately handles the METAR standard format, including multiple levels of cloud cover. Please review the changes below.

In our updateRoomWeather function, let's create one low-opacity "sky sphere" for each level of skyConditions we have. Use opacity of .2, set our sphere object's scale to 10 * cloudBaseFtAgl, and set a different color for each of the understood skyCover values.

I've updated the `updateRoomWeather` function to create low-opacity sky spheres based on the `skyConditions` data. Each sphere's opacity is set to 0.2, its scale is calculated as `10 * cloudBaseFtAgl`, and its color corresponds to the `skyCover` value. Please review the color assignments and let me know if you have specific color preferences for each sky condition.

Instead of using room.getElementsByTagName, let's store our spheres as this.skySpheres as we create them.

Also, our skySphere objects should be type "object" with id="sphere".

Understood. I have updated the `weather-metar.js` file to store sky spheres in `this.skySpheres` and changed their type to `"object"` with `id="sphere"`. Please review the changes below and let me know if you have any further adjustments or questions.
